title: Tune in to our playtester stream on Wednesday from 6 to 8 PM PDT!
body:
Hey guys! I'm Don "Aesah" Ding on Riot's Playtest team, a group of Diamond+ players who play with the new champions, reworks, balance tweaks, items, map updates, etc. before they are released. It's our job to the test the ideas that our developers come up with and ensure that we're introducing positive changes to LoL in terms of both balance and fun.

I host the Playtest Stream along with another member of our team every Wednesday from 6 to 8 PM Pacific Time. The main focus of the stream is to answer any questions you guys have for us. We will also be playing games with viewers (in a custom game where the password is announced in the chat) and delivering a few high level gameplay tips.

All of us on the Playtest Team are avid gamers so feel free to talk to us as fellow LoL players. While we can't answer specific questions about anything that would be considered confidential or a leak, you guys can also use this opportunity to ask us anything about Riot. 

Feel free to use this thread to leave any questions, suggestions, or comments about the Playtest Stream, and see you guys at www.twitch.tv/leagueoflegends!

EDIT: as of 9/28/16, this stream will be on hiatus. I'm not exactly sure how long but definitely AT LEAST a few months.

replies.body: here is my question, supposedly the majority of the player base is located in gold and below... why is the game play tested and balanced to plat+?

The game is not balanced solely for plat+. It's a common misconception though- in fact one of the most frequent complaints I've seen from players is that X champion isn't performing well in high levels of play, therefore he needs buffs. However we definitely care about other brackets, aka the majority of our playerbase.

Balancing is done with all brackets in mind, but a disproportionate (in the mathematical, neutral meaning of the word) attention is still given to high brackets, I hope. 'Cause if a champion is "OP" in low levels, the counter-play does exist already, it's just that people don't know it or how to execute on it. Whereas a champion that is "OP" in high levels, well, it's just actually OP, without quotes.

So of course, Riot has to take care of the situation if a champion is balanced for LCS but has a 70% winrate in Bronze, of course that's not a sustainable state for the game. But the game MUST be precisely balanced at high levels, whereas at lower levels, it just needs to not have too many too big outliers.
